title: Natalie Portmanâ€™s New Movie Arco Is An Animated Wake-Up Call About Climate Change
text:
Natalie Portmanâ€™s New Movie Arco Is An Animated Wake-Up Call About Climate Change

The world is both a literal and metaphorical hellscape right now, and no one knows that better than Natalie Portman. The actress, vegan, and longtime climate activist has been at the forefront of calls for climate change and awareness throughout her decades-long career. And now, sheâ€™s using animation to further the cause. In Arco, a newly-released animated film from French director and illustrator Ugo Bienvenu and produced by Portman, audiences are introduced to the not-so-distant future. Except in this version of Earth, in the year 2075, those tsunamis and wild fires that are becoming increasingly frequent and more devastating? Theyâ€™re essentially the norm; with homes outfitted with glass domes that offer protection during bouts of extreme weather. Itâ€™s here that we meet Iris, an adventurous 10-year-old looking for adventure out of her day-to-day. When, one day, she rescues Arco, a time-travelling kid transported from the future, it becomes a story on the power and impact of friendship, in more ways than one.Â 

Because with him, Arco brings realities of the future. Due to the impact of climate change, Arco and his family â€” along with their neighbours â€” no longer live on Earth, moving up to tree branch-like homes in the sky that allow for the planet to repair and regenerate without human interruption. Itâ€™s a surprising, albeit not so hard to imagine reality; and one made even more impactful through Bienvenuâ€™s use of animation, which is able to engage viewers while presenting an impactful message.Â 

â€œAnimation to me is one of the best mediums for storytelling,â€ Bienvenu, whose other works includes short films Dolly Zero and 2019â€™s Lâ€™entretien, tells Refinery29. This is for a very particular reason, specifically, the way animated films resonate with viewers, often re-watching from when theyâ€™re kids all the way up to when they become adults, and choose to share their favourite movies, be it Aladdin, The Fox and the Hound or Coco, with their own children. â€œ[You watch] animation movies all over your life, they accompany you all your life. And making a movie is long, so I wanted to do something that could have a [long] impact on the people that would watch it.â€

And in many instances, itâ€™s kids who are going to change the world â€” often in inventive ways. This is a truth made clear as Iris tries to help Arco get home, all while navigating changing environmental elements (Arco needs very specific weather â€” sunny with rain â€” to time travel) and a society thatâ€™s essentially run by drones. On the surface, it may seem like an engaging and earnest story about the bonds of friendship â€“ and it is â€” but thereâ€™s something deeper to it, too.

As Iris and Arco try tirelessly to set up the perfect environmental conditions for him to return home, covering Irisâ€™s front lawn in pillows and couch cushions for Arco to jump into and setting the sprinkler to go off at the exact right moment, thereâ€™s an underlying frustration with their inability to do so, and with the knowledge that those conditions, now in this current climate, are unlikely to come naturally. Arcoâ€™s stranded; a feeling probably akin to what many young people feel today when it comes to thinking about our planet.Â 

But Arco and Iris donâ€™t give up. Instead, continuing to press forward, determined that thereâ€™s a way to help Arco get home.Â 

It was this optimistic way of looking at challenges, so inherent in Bienvenuâ€™s story, and children in general, that drew Portman to the project in the first place. The actress recalls seeing early animatics of Arco and talking to director Bienvenu about his vision for the film â€” one in which creativity and imagination can be put towards a better future for our climate. â€œWith environmental concerns, it was [usually] an attitude of â€˜itâ€™s difficult,â€™ but look at what imagination can bring,â€™â€ Portman says of this perspective. â€œThere was hope and active participation in making the future through creativity. And I thought that was a very beautiful, activating way to look at a situation that weâ€™re often kind of fatalistic about.â€Â 

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Refinery29 (@refinery29)

And rightfully so. With climate change expected to cause approximately 250,000 additional deaths per year globally between 2030 and 2050, according to data from The World Health Organization(WHO), it can be easy to count ourselves â€“ and our planet â€” out; resign ourselves to give up trying to change our behaviour in the present, knowing that weâ€™re already so far gone. But, Arco â€” and the team behind the movie â€” wants us to forget about the future, or more specifically, think that they know how the future will play out. Which is why, when Iris tries to follow Arco home, he encourages her to stay in the present, stating: â€œNo one should know the future â€” ever.â€Â 

It seems like a surprising sentiment, given the fact most young people have grown up being told that, when it comes to the environment and climate change, the future is the only thing we should be thinking about â€” and how our actions now will impact our children, grandchildren and great grandchildren long after weâ€™re gone.Â Â Â Â Â 

â€œIf you know the future, it gives you no agency in the present. You think, â€˜Oh, thatâ€™s how itâ€™s gonna be, so [thereâ€™s] nothing I can do about it,â€™â€ Portman says. â€œIf you accept that you donâ€™t know what the futureâ€™s going to be like, then you have a part in changing it and affecting it.â€

Which is what we, as viewers, eventually see. While we donâ€™t see what happens to Arco after he travels home, audiences do get a glimpse into what Iris takes from her time with her new friend; primarily, inspiration to go forth and make a difference for her own future. Through small glimpses at photos and sketches in Irisâ€™ room, audiences see that the curious, intelligent, vivacious 10-year-old weâ€™re first introduced to will go on toÂ  use that curiosity and vivaciousness to try and create a better future for the planet, going on to calculate, sketch and create the more sustainable world Arco will one day inhabit.Â 

Itâ€™s a lesson on the impact one person can have for both kids and viewers who are coming to the film as adults already. While Arcoâ€™s main audience demographic may initially seem to be those under 12-years-old, â€œwe want to speak to the kids that are still in ourselves,â€ Bienvenu adds,â€ because we still are kids in a way; a big part of me is still a kid and I want to feed that part of myself.â€

Arco is in theatres November 14.Â

title: What Do We Lose When Black Women In Journalism Disappear? Everything.
text:
What Do We Lose When Black Women In Journalism Disappear? Everything.

On November 3, CondÃ© Nast â€”Â the media company that owns Vogue, Vanity Fair, The New Yorker, GQ, and Wired, amongst other outlets â€”Â announced that Teen Vogue would be absorbed into Vogue.com. The news came two months after the publication was awarded the Roosevelt Instituteâ€™s 2025 Freedom of Speech and Expression Award, and followed nearly a decadeâ€™s worth of coverage of politics and other important cultural topics in a way that was relevant and accessible to a primarily Gen-Z audience.Â 

Beyond its categorically political reporting, Teen Vogue was lauded for its dedication to intersectionality, and the way it approached issues impacting Black, Indigenous, and other people of color (BIPOC) and marginalized groups more generally across all its verticals. Whether that be a piece holding fashion brands to account for diversity promises made in 2020, an op-ed on Robert F. Kennedy and autism, or choosing transgender model and social media star, Vivian Wilson, as its digital cover star â€” giving her the opportunity to publicly admonish both her estranged father, Elon Musk, and his bestie, Trump.Â 

The publicationâ€™s reorganization came with several notable layoffs. Editor-In-Chief Versha Sharma and seven staff members lost their jobs, leaving Teen Vogue with zero Black women or trans folks on its staff.Â 

In a post to her Instagram, former Editor-In-Chief Elaine Welteroth, who presided over the magazine during its dedicated shift to political coverage circa 2015 and 2016, said the magazine â€œwas a once-in-a-generation experiment in what happens when you hand the mic to young people from diverse backgrounds and take their voices seriously.â€Â 

This, against the backdrop of an industry in which just 15% of reporters who cover social issues and policy are Black, according to a 2022 Pew Research study. Those numbers drop to just 7% of entertainment and travel reporters, and 5% of those covering government and politics. At a time when diversity, equity, and inclusion gains are being clawed back or ignored completely in boardrooms and at a cultural level, the dismissal of such a talented newsroom begs the question: What necessary perspectives do we lose, and what questions go unasked and unanswered, when Black journalists are among the first to be seen as disposable on a masthead?

Among those let go at Teen Vogue last month was Kaitlyn McNab, an award-winning journalist and the outletâ€™s former Culture Editor. Her love for the outlet was homegrown, as it was one she regularly reached out to when she was a freelance writer, dating back to early winter 2020 when she first pitched a story for Valentineâ€™s Day about diverse young adult love stories.Â 

â€œ[I was pitching Black stories] every single day. That has always been at the forefront of my beat and perspective as a journalist,â€ says McNab, who had also overseen writing and editing for Teen Vogueâ€™s Identity section and served as its Entertainment Editor during her five-year tenure. â€œA lot of the work that Iâ€™m most proud of from my time at Teen Vogue are features and interviews that allowed Black women specifically, to feel safe enough to talk about their careers, lives, and experiences and also to trust me with asking harder questions.â€

That included an interview with rapper Ice Spice, marking â€œone of the first where she talked to another Black woman and I think we were able to talk about things that she hadnâ€™t touched on in other stories,â€ McNab explains.Â 

Unfortunately, layoffs are quite common â€” 40% of workers will experience it at least once in their career.Â  But this current moment feels different, like itâ€™s about more than just dollars and cents. In a year that has seen the president and his top advisors openly attack free speech and slash funding for public broadcasting, the silencing, stifling, and degradation of diverse voices via trustworthy platforms is a harbinger of a larger, more sinister cultural shift. All of this is happening at a time where companies are rolling back DEI initiatives and the administration threatens others to do the same. At a time where harmful AI-generated videos of Black women using SNAP benefits continuously show up online. At a time where Black women overall lost the most number of jobs this year.Â Â Â 

â€œWhen there are economic downturns, Black workers who are the so-called professional class â€” which just basically means people with a college degree â€” actually do worse in terms of wage downturns [than their white counterparts],â€ says Dr. Ofronama Biu, Chief Economist and Senior Research Director at The Maven Collaborative, a Black and brown woman-led organization working to create a new, inclusive economy.Â 

Black women, historically, are cultural and economic indicators. Despite participating in the workforce at a higher rate than any other demographic, unemployment rates amongst Black women have been rising at twice the rate of white and Asian women, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. And after losing a job, Black women tend to remain unemployed for longer than other workers â€” a worrying trend that dates back to the Great Recession. â€œThe hit that the economy [takes] gets turned on Black workers more than their white counterparts, and even more so when theyâ€™re in the professional class,â€ Biu explains.Â 

Yet in spite of the hardship, Black women continue to shift the economy and culture. And we care deeply: about our communities, and the people in them, and the problems they face. In my opinion, writers often feel similarly because many of us entered this profession believing that itâ€™s an honor to be entrusted with other peopleâ€™s stories. And we feel a burden to handle those stories justly. But as a Black journalist, I sometimes find myself wondering: Why do we dedicate ourselves to an industry that seems so irreverent about us?

This isnâ€™t just a CondÃ© Nast problem. Changing winds are being felt all across the industry. Earlier this year, MSNBC (owned by NBCUniversal) did its own â€œreshuffling,â€ ultimately firing Joy Reid, a prominent Black political commentator and outspoken Trump critic, and canceling her award-winning primetime show. NBCUniversal struck again in October, gutting 150 staffers from NBC News and announcing it would eliminate the teams dedicated to covering marginalized issues. That same month, VIBE, the long-running music magazine focused on rap, hip-hop, and R&B coverage launched by music mogul Quincy Jones announced that it would merge with Rolling Stone. The statement speaks of plans to re-establish the magazine as a driving force for music reporting and amplify its presence across all platforms. It did not, however, say this: it all comes at the expense of VIBEâ€™s almost entirely Black newsroom.

â€œI didnâ€™t know it was coming,â€ says former VIBE staffer and R&B reporter Mya Abraham. â€œI woke up one day and had a meeting on my calendar I thought was weird.â€ In that meeting, a human resources representative told Abraham that the companyâ€™s decision to restructure was not based on performance. Almost all of her colleagues, she says, got a similar call.

Also in October, CBS News laid off about 100 employees, including eight on-air correspondents and hosts â€” all women, half of whom are people of color. Under the newly-minted leadership of Bari Weiss â€”Â a former opinion columnist who has openly called for the end of DEI programs â€“ the network also axed its Race and Culture Unit, which was created in 2020 after the murder of George Floyd and ensuing surge of Black Lives Matter protests. Established newsrooms at Pitchfork and HuffPost also saw substantial layoffs this year.

Are we noticing the pattern yet? This is not just economic anxiety â€” itâ€™s cultural erasure, a rollback of DEI promises, and loss of platforms where Black and underrepresented voices are heard. The exact places where we created spaces are being dismantled. In these layoffs, weâ€™re not just losing recipes, weâ€™re losing cooks, and access to kitchens too.

Inclusion begets diversity. And diversity encourages accountability. Thatâ€™s what makes these media layoffs especially troubling. As one of the most visible pathways for trusted information, the gutting of dedicated newsrooms represents the erasure of dozens of voices who can speak to BIPOC, queer, and underrepresented issues from a place of authority. Without a newsroom of writers and editors like Abraham and McNab, coverage loses its luster. What was once a kaleidoscope of perspectives runs the risk of suddenly becoming very dull.Â 

â€œI asked [Ice Spice] directly about the discourse around her success, colorism, and comparisons to other female rap artists, namely Flo Milli,â€ McNab points out. Her cultural awareness and sensitivity made the interview better. It also reignited a necessary conversation about the music industryâ€™s more harmful beliefs and stereotypes.

While publications like Essence, Ebony, Bustle, and, of course, Unbothered still exist, full-time staff jobs are fewer and far between. In response to the increasing precarity of their chosen profession, many writers are choosing to put fate into their own hands. A recent study by Muck Rack found that out of 1,515 surveyed journalists, more than a third of respondents independently publish their own content. Abraham will soon be one of them â€” sheâ€™s launching a podcast and Substack called â€œPlay The B Sidesâ€, dedicated to covering all things R&B. McNab, though, isnâ€™t sure the independent creator life is for her.Â 

For all its flaws, the media industry â€œdoes, in a sense, give us stability,â€ she says. â€œEven though itâ€™s so precarious, it gives us health insurance. It gives us a safety net.â€ For now, her immediate priority is to recuperate. â€œMy therapist already dragged me for trying to think too far ahead. She was like, â€˜You were dangerously burnt out and you need to take this time to rest right now.â€™â€

Any work (no matter how glamorous the â€˜00s rom-com makes it seem) is a job. It can be stressful, but it also provides a steady source of income. When that suddenly vanishes, thereâ€™s so much to practically consider: severance packages, contracts, figuring out how â€” or if â€” youâ€™re going to be able to afford your life moving forward. Given the disparities for Black women and other minorities regarding savings accounts and other safety nets, the loss of even one paycheck can feel catastrophic. After all, itâ€™s hard to save money for the future when youâ€™re being paid significantly less than your white counterparts to begin with.

For her part, Abraham started a GoFundMe for herself and her ex-colleagues as they begin to figure out next steps. Despite receiving more than 21,000 views on X (formerly Twitter), the effort has only raised $1,100 of a $35,000 total goal. When I asked if sheâ€™s disappointed by that, she admits she is. â€œIâ€™m just like, â€˜OK, how hard do I have to fight to get this goal met?â€™,â€ she says. â€œThere is still a whole team of Black journalists who donâ€™t have a job anymore.â€Â 

But as a self-described optimist, Abraham remains hopeful â€”Â for her future, for the industry she loves, and most importantly, for her community.Â 

â€œIâ€™m just here to support everybody Black,â€ she says, invoking a now-famous Issa Rae quote. â€œThatâ€™s all I want to do â€” support Black things because we deserve it. We are the driving force of the culture. And I just want the world to remember that.â€

title: Hourglass Founder Carisa Janesâ€™ On Her New Brand: â€œI Want To Surpriseâ€
text:
Hourglass Founder Carisa Janesâ€™ On Her New Brand: â€œI Want To Surpriseâ€

When it comes to legacy beauty foundersâ€™ second acts, Carisa Janes is in excellent company. From Bobbi Brownâ€™s Jones Road to Ali Webbâ€™s Messy (her sophomore endeavor following Drybar), some of the most exciting beauty brands of the moment are coming from longtime tastemakers.Â 

With Hourglass, Janes famously honed a luxury makeup POV with a focus on lit-from-within, sculpted skin powered by baked Ambient light powders that made the brand a household name. With her latest venture, Outside In, sheâ€™s not just creating more product for productsâ€™ sake. The brand is launching with just three products, a Silk Serum Foundation, an accompanying brush, and Floral Reserve Face Oil.

The foundation notably features skincare-grade levels of active ingredients like niacinamide and hyaluronic acid, and the face oil features a base of sweet almond, sunflower seed, and meadowfoam seed oils.Â â€œI really want to surprise,â€ Janes says. â€œThatâ€™s what that drives me the most with Hourglass and Outside In: the opportunity to create something special.â€

Letâ€™s start with the foundation: IMO, itâ€™s much more of a skin tint (but a really good one) than actual foundation, since it looks virtually undetectable on skin and actually feels like hydrating skincare that happens to have pigment in the formula.Â Available in 25 sheer shades, the formula combines the dewiness of a hydrating serum base with light-diffusing spherical powders for a visibly even complexion with a blurred, soft-focus effect. And while the bottle looks and feels incredibly luxe, itâ€™s secretly sustainable, too. â€œWhat took the longest [in the process] was actually the packaging because itâ€™s made from a rice husk-derived biomaterial, and recycled glass,â€ Janes tells me. The result? A beautiful, stone-like texture that youâ€™ll want to proudly leave on countertops.

Face oils might be relegated to a final step of skincare to â€œlock inâ€ preceding products, but not this one. Janes loves using this as a primer (!) for Silk Serum Foundation to create a hydrated, glowy base that doesnâ€™t require illuminating products. (Which, ironically, one could say she has mastered with Hourglass.) â€œI want to challenge myself to create really unique products,â€ she tells me. Think: Vegan brushes with a limestone composite handle and a forthcoming brick-and-mortar store that brings an experiential aspect of the brand to life. (If the packaging doesnâ€™t give it away, Janes is passionate about design and world-building via her products.)

Priced at $64 for the foundation, $52 for the brush, and $72 for the face oil, these are as far from cheap thrills as it gets. But just as you might invest in a luxury candle for your home or an investment coat to wear all season long, Janes is hoping to inspire a sort of keepsake-like longevity with Outside In. â€œI want the customer to have that feeling of desirability and like, â€˜This is something I really cherish and love,'â€ Janes says. â€œThatâ€™s what Iâ€™m trying to do with every product launch with Outside In.â€

For so many of us, working out and going to the gym is a hobby or something we do to stay healthy. For you, itâ€™s been your job. How do you separate the work of staying active from the joy of it and doing it just because it makes you feel good?Â 

SB: Now, Iâ€™ve started to explore other hobbies that still include working out, but it just looks a little bit different. Right now, although Iâ€™m not in the gym 24/7, Iâ€™m in my horseback riding lessons, and Iâ€™m about to pick up ice skating lessons because I feel like gymnastics, although it was working out, it was just it was so much fun for me and you donâ€™t even realize youâ€™re exercising. So I wanted to feel that similar feeling. I took up horseback riding because going to a gym for me and doing pilates and all that stuff seems a little bit scary and daunting, but if you put it as a hobby, and say â€œIâ€™m working out for an hour or so,â€ it feels a little bit easier. Iâ€™m about to start doing my ice skating lessons. Iâ€™ve already called the ice rink. I know theyâ€™re tired of hearing from me [laughs].Â 

What made you decide to do ice skating?

SB: The â€‹â€‹rink is literally three minutes from my house and since I pass it all the time going to and from the airport, Iâ€™m like, okay, thatâ€™s going to be a fun, little hobby. I walk my dog and I have a weighted vest but just going on walks and seeing the leaves change in the fall is also fun for me. I donâ€™t think Iâ€™m ready to just get into a gym just yet, unless itâ€™s a girlsâ€™ activity and weâ€™re doing pilates or weâ€™re doing something cute. I donâ€™t think Iâ€™m ready. I still want to have fun with it. Just random sidequests.Â 

Iâ€™m Canadian so I love to see Black girls doing winter sports.Â 

SB: Yes! We can do it all. Iâ€™ve never seen as much representation as I have these days, and itâ€™s so exciting. Itâ€™s inspiring me. At the end of the day, I donâ€™t just have to be a gymnast. I can do it all because Iâ€™ve seen us do it all.

Yes, you can. One thing we love seeing you do is show up on NFL game days supporting your husband. Will we be seeing a custom Athleta game day set soon?

SB: Yeah! Itâ€™s coming soon. Weâ€™re planning on not this weekend but the next weekend in Minnesota. A little custom bomber going on, okay! Got a little custom action coming.Â 

Take me through what goes on behind your game-day fashion. How do you put your outfits together for games?Â 

SB: I really try to base it on the weather and where theyâ€™re playing. My husband wants me to wear more navy and orange [for the teamâ€™s colors], but Iâ€™m always going with the blacks and the whites and the grays and the neutrals. Iâ€™m trying to implement a little bit more of the Bearsâ€™ colors. But other than that, I really base it off of the weather. I know later this year when we play in San Francisco, you can get a little bit more cute and fashionable, because for me, with my height, itâ€™s so hard to be cute and look fashionable [in the cold] when Iâ€™m just going to walk around looking like a marshmallow. I try to implement certain things like that. But definitely, we have a couple things coming, and so Iâ€™m really excited about that. But weather first and foremost, and comfortability, comfortability, comfortability! And movement!Â 

I saw a headline today that said: â€˜Is Simone Biles NFLâ€™s Best WAG?â€™ How do you feel about that title?Â 

SB: I donâ€™t know about that! We still got Ciara, we got Normani. We can all fit in that space! Thereâ€™s room for all of us.Â 

It feels like thereâ€™s so much attention on WAGs, specifically football wives and girlfriends. How do you feel about the term WAG and being a part of that club with, as you said, with Ciara and Normani, and then thereâ€™s [Hailee Steinfeld and Taylor Swift] and all these people?

SB: I donâ€™t mind the word WAG, because really, Iâ€™m just showing up and supporting my husband. Although the fashion is so much fun to do, Iâ€™m really just there to go support my man, and that is really important that we get to show up and support one another. Weâ€™re always working so hard, and we have a limited amount of time with each other. We donâ€™t know how long each of us are going to be professional athletes playing on a stage like this. Itâ€™s so much fun. But again, there are a lot of eyes. SB: Iâ€™m only on the field because thatâ€™s my husbandâ€™s good luck thing. He knows that he has to have me on the sideline. He said thatâ€™s his one thing. Heâ€™s not superstitious at all, but heâ€™s like, â€œI know I have to have my girl on the field, get that good luck kiss, and then weâ€™re good.â€ If not, yâ€™all would never see me down there. I would be up in the stands hiding like yâ€™all would never see me. But thatâ€™s my husbandâ€™s thing so thatâ€™s why I do it.Â

SB: Iâ€™d be hiding. I donâ€™t like the attention â€” never have, and maybe never will. That stuff stresses me out so bad, I will be hiding as much as possible. I donâ€™t like all of this attention but you get used to it, I guess. But itâ€™s stress! Anxiety! I just want to just go do my thing and watch in peace and quiet. Next year, I think Iâ€™m going to stay home for the away games. I just canâ€™t do it. Iâ€™m just so stressed. Thereâ€™s a lot of behind-the-scenes logistics that goes into it as well. Speaking of stress, Iâ€™m also an anxious girlie. Weâ€™re Unbothered so we always like to do a Black girl mental health check in. Youâ€™ve been so outspoken about mental health and the importance of therapy, especially Therapy Thursdays. Is there a piece of advice or something youâ€™ve learned in therapy that you can share with us, with our audience, who are mostly Black women? Give us some energy! We need it!Â 

SB: I would say the one piece of advice that I have is you have to take that mental time to yourself and those personal days, because it really does change how you feel, talk about yourself, what your life looks like. So I would say, take those personal days. Itâ€™s really important to stay in tune and to listen to your body and your mind, because that literally can change the trajectory of your life. We have to put ourselves first.

One of the things that is so inspiring about you is that you are the best. And in being the best gymnast in the world, the best athlete in the world, you inspire me to think I can be the best at what I do. But I also think of the pressure or expectation that comes with that. Whatâ€™s something youâ€™re just OK at, and is there freedom in being mediocre sometimes?Â 

SB: Every day with me and my husband, weâ€™re learning new recipes. Since Iâ€™ve done my craft for so long, over 22 years, itâ€™s really hard for me. I love learning new things, but Iâ€™m always learning, and keen to keep learning. It never ends. Iâ€™m learning every day. I know Iâ€™m not going to be the best at it. We even did a wine and sip the other day. Did my painting look the best? Absolutely not. But I donâ€™t care. Iâ€™m not trying to be the best. I didnâ€™t train 22 years to paint so it looks like what it looks like, and every day when Iâ€™m doing new recipes in the house, because now I love to cook, I love to cook, itâ€™s OK.

Iâ€™m even trying to get better at my makeup and my hair. I was just bugging one of my makeup artists yesterday, like, girl, you really try not to have me be great at makeup, because I keep asking you to send me the tutorial, and she finally sent it to me yesterday. So now today, Iâ€™m going to go look at it, and Iâ€™m going to go practice my makeup. We always have more to learn. Iâ€™m okay with that. I love playing darts. I love playing ping pong. At our new house, which we sign for next week, we have a ping pong table and a dart board. Am I the best at it? No, but itâ€™s about making memories, having fun and just still learning.

I love that but I can also picture the competitive spirit in you trying to come out at the paint and sip.Â 

SB: You know, thatâ€™s actually so funny, because everyone thinks Iâ€™m going to be so competitive at whatever we do, but I literally donâ€™t care if Iâ€™m last place. Every time, Iâ€™m still going to play, Iâ€™m still going to have a good spirit, good energy, because itâ€™s about making those memories. Obviously for them, theyâ€™re like, â€œI beat Simone Biles at something!â€ I donâ€™t care. I donâ€™t care. Letâ€™s just have a good time. Letâ€™s kiki, have a good time, good conversation, good vibes, good energy. And thatâ€™s a win in my book, because weâ€™re not going to be good at everything. Iâ€™m incredibly gifted, and to do what I do every day has been such a blessing and to come out on top. But I also know thatâ€™s not normal. I know thatâ€™s very rare. So Iâ€™m just incredibly blessed and thankful.Â 

Thatâ€™s inspiring that Simone Biles can be so chill about losing or being bad at something.Â 

SB: Yeah, well I never wanted to be the best at gymnastics. I just wanted to go to college, hopefully get a college scholarship, and that was it. Obviously, the cards fell in place, and I got to do way more than my wildest dreams. But even as a young girl, did I want to go to the Olympics? No. Every one of my teammates said that. So I said it. I donâ€™t even know what the Olympics was. I saw it in 2008 on the TV. And I was like, Whoa. Howâ€™d they do that? But I didnâ€™t even want to go there. At that point. I saw the girls [gymnastics team] and they went to Italy. And I was like, how do I go to Italy? I want to compete in Italy. I never wanted to go to the Olympics. You just dream big and dream bigger.

You were dreaming dreams you didnâ€™t even know you had. Speaking of your teammates, you competed on Dancing with the Stars and now so is Jordan Chiles. Sheâ€™s killing it. Are you watching? How proud of Jordan are you?

SB: Oh my god, Iâ€™m so proud of her. Sheâ€™s totally in her element. This is what she was made to do. Sheâ€™s always been an entertainer, and obviously that goes hand-in-hand with gymnastics. On floor [routines], we do have to entertain a little bit, but this is her space completely. And she gets to be 100% herself. People get to see her personality shine. Itâ€™s a little glimpse of what weâ€™ve gotten to see over the past couple of years, but now she gets to share it with the whole world.

Did you give her any advice going into the season?Â

Now I think Iâ€™m a little bit more comfortable in who I am, but this is perfect for her. So there was no advice, just â€œgood luck, have fun.â€ And I told her, â€œyouâ€™re going to be on that show one day.â€ And sheâ€™s like, â€œNo, I donâ€™t think so.â€ Girl, look at you now! I said â€œtheyâ€™re going to keep asking you and bugging you to do it.â€ And sheâ€™s like, â€œNo, I donâ€™t think so.â€ And now sheâ€™s like, â€œwhy are you always right?â€ I know these things. Itâ€™s like a sixth sense.

I love being the friend whoâ€™s always right.Â 

SB: Yeah, I get badgered about that a lot. â€œYouâ€™re just always right!â€ OK. And am!Â

My It-Girl Tumbler Blender Is My Emotional Support Object

Refinery29 is proud to partner with SharkNinja, purveyor of high-quality products and appliances designed to make your life easier â€” like the Ninja BlendBOSSâ„¢, a powerful tumbler blender for when youâ€™re on the go. One fan of the Ninja BlendBOSSâ„¢ is Samantha Feher, a 28-year-old New York City-based podcaster, entrepreneur, and content creator. Here, in this personal essay, as told to Andrea Cheng, she opens up and gets vulnerable about her wellness journey, her new approach to health and fitness, and how the Ninja BlendBOSSâ„¢ seamlessly fits into her everyday routine.Â Â 

Two years ago, I was in a pretty bad place. I cried, like, every day. Not that youâ€™d know it â€” I appeared on millions of Americansâ€™ TV screens every Monday night with a smile plastered on my face, reminding everyone that summer should be fun. I was thrust into the national spotlight after being cast in a reality show. There, I met (and started dating) a man who was justâ€¦not very nice to me. But sometimes really nice. And then really not nice again. I think the kids call it a â€œtoxic relationship.â€ So I was navigating that, which left me in a spiral of insecurity and depression and anxiety, and simultaneously dealing with snarky commentary from the millions of people watching it play out.

I felt like I was under a magnifying glass, with everyone on earth seeing the worst parts of my life up close. All I could think about was how I was perceived, so I started living my life according to what I thought these people thought of me. In short, I was living two lives: one of red carpets and toothy grins, which mostly felt disingenuous â€” and one that was more honest, but totally miserable. It was only when my relationship ended that I realized how much of a toll it had taken on me, both physically and mentally. There wasnâ€™t anything wrong with me, I realized â€” there was something wrong withâ€¦well, that.Â 

So I decided to embark on a healing journey (insert sparkle emojis here). In November 2023, I overhauled my life, determined to â€œdo the work.â€ Signs of trauma had already shown up in my body: I was inflamed, I was bloated, and my skin was breaking out. I researched anti-inflammatory nutrition and changed my workout routine accordingly. I took care of my inner self: I went to therapy, I journaled, I unpacked some hard stuff, I took breaks from social media, I spent quality time with friends and family.Â 

Throughout this two-year journey, I learned to prioritize my mental and physical health. But the biggest takeaway was learning about health in a whole new light â€” one thatâ€™s not entirely accessible nor intuitive. Thereâ€™s a dearth of health information written by women, for women, and about women. For example: the importance of lifting weights. Iâ€™m on a body recomposition journey (sounds intimidating, I know, but hear me out) thatâ€™s basically an effort to eat more protein, carbohydrates, and fats. All it really means is that Iâ€™m trying to gain muscle, because skeletal muscle mass is directly correlated to how long we live. Simply put: I want to be strong. I want to build muscle so that I can live longer, so that I can pick things up, so that I donâ€™t get injured when I work out. So that even if my heart gets broken, my mind and body remain in one piece.

And to be completely honest, I canâ€™t do it without my Ninja BlendBOSSâ„¢. Iâ€™ve always been a smoothie girly, but my protein shakes have become an integral part of my daily routine, especially once I discovered that I needed to drastically up my protein intake. Now I can hardly make it out the door without my stomach growling if I donâ€™t start my morning by blending up a protein shake (mine tastes like dessert, I swear), and I canâ€™t recover afterwards without my 100 ounces of water, powdered supplements, or my homemade electrolyte concoction.

The Ninja BlendBOSSâ„¢ is kind of like an everything-in-one product â€” itâ€™s a blender, a tumbler, a bottle, conveniently housed in an easy-to-use (and super chic) vessel. Itâ€™s for the busy mom on the go, for the hydration queen whose emotional support object is her water bottle (me), for the fitness It girl who doesnâ€™t like stray from her routine (also me).Â 

If youâ€™ve never fueled with a goal in mind, itâ€™s hard to even understand what kind of a lifesaver this is. I always do a big existential sigh when women say they avoid lifting weights because theyâ€™re â€œafraid of getting bulky.â€ If only they knew how much food theyâ€™d have to eat to achieve such a thing. Since Iâ€™m trying to hit 125g of protein, 225g of carbs, and 50g of fat, adding protein powder, peanut butter, bananas, and Greek yogurt into a shake allows me to consume at least 30g of protein before Iâ€™m even out the door in the morning. Thanks to the Ninja BlendBOSSâ„¢, Iâ€™m hitting my numbers in a way thatâ€™s healthy and enjoyable.

For almost all my life, the driving force when it came to my physical appearance was to look a certain way for other people, to fit what I thought was the beauty standardâ€¦which, to be blunt, was skinny. As a kid, with my blonde hair and blue eyes, I grew up hearing that I looked like a doll, and I spent my whole life feeling like I was supposed to look the part. That meant being a size double zero, having visible abs, and making sure my hair, makeup, and nails were always done.Â 

I should mention that I was a ballerina growing up, with the plan to go pro (I lost out to a career-ending injury at 16). Anyone whoâ€™s ever done ballet will know that many studios are breeding grounds for body image issues. Clad in light pink leotards and tights, dancers almost invariably hear â€œI can see your lunch,â€ (as inâ€¦they can see your stomach) more times than they hear â€œgreat workâ€ before the age of 13.

Historically, women are trained to think that getting in shape means losing weight â€” and losing weight means more cardio and less food. For so long, that was my mindset, too. I used to frequent HIIT classes, which are optimized for higher heart rates and dropping pounds. But two of my trainers over the years â€” Taylor Rae Roman and Madison Feeney â€” both of whom I now consider friends, reshaped my thinking. Through them, I learned to prioritize strong over skinny.

Iâ€™ll confess: When I first set out to build muscle, I was terrified. As a dancer, creator, and public figure, Iâ€™ve always been hyper-aware of what my body looked and felt like. I thought: What if I look in the mirror and donâ€™t recognize myself? I already know that there will be times I pick myself apart â€” pinching parts of me, second-guessing, and worrying what other people think. Those are habits you donâ€™t unlearn in a day.

But the motivation to do this is for myself â€” not for other people. And itâ€™s not easy, but if Iâ€™ve learned anything on this journey, itâ€™s that everything worth doing is hard. Already, Iâ€™m seeing a difference. Just this morning, I noticed that my body looked a little bigger. But I also noticed something more important, more exciting: the voice inside my head that shouted out my wins drowned out the voice that whispered my fears. I picked up a 45-pound weight instead of a 40-pound one. I climbed the five flights of stairs to my apartment without feeling out of breath. I felt hungry for every meal, because, finally, Iâ€™m supporting my body with nutrients in a way that actually makes my metabolism go faster. It all feels so rewarding and encouraging, because itâ€™s how your body is supposed to operate. To the untrained eye, these changes are too subtle to notice, but theyâ€™re a big deal to me.

You know the saying, â€œYou have to love yourself before someone else can love youâ€? I really used to think it was BS. But I must say: Iâ€™m not sure itâ€™s a coincidence that the first time I started to love myself â€” six-ish months into my healing journey â€” is also when my boyfriend and I started dating. And I donâ€™t think itâ€™s a coincidence that this is the healthiest, happiest relationship Iâ€™ve ever known. Every single thing thatâ€™s good in your life comes from loving yourself. If you take care of yourself, you can feel strong, powerful. Beautiful. Lovable.

Anyway, if youâ€™ve made it this far, you must be wondering where Iâ€™ve ended up. To answer your question: Iâ€™m still in it. Because despite society convincing us that thereâ€™s a â€œbeforeâ€ and â€œafterâ€ for every journey, the truth is: Itâ€™s never really over. But I have settled on my destination. After all this soul searching, this healing, I feel like itâ€™s my duty to share this message with other women who are going through the same things. I know how many of them are 30 minutes into their excruciating spin classes, thinking, If Iâ€™m just one inch smaller, maybe someone will love me. Iâ€™ve been there. I know what itâ€™s like to outsource your identity and self-respect to the opinions of others. It sucks. So if I can help even one person change that mindset, or even pursue a goal of being stronger and healthier for themselves, and no one elseâ€¦then Iâ€™d go through all the pain again, so we could find ourselves here, together, now. It would all be worth it.
